Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws C.raw_text: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, this Court has the authority to modify a custody order upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances warranting such modification.
Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws C.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, this Court has the authority to modify a custody order upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances warranting such modification.

- Kelly v. Kelly, 412 Mass. 151 (1992).proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Kelly v. Kelly, 412 Mass. 151 (1992).support_reasoning: The quoted text is from Commonwealth v. Rosa, not Kelly v. Kelly, and it deals with prosecutorial misuse of impeachment evidence and spousal privilege issues in a criminal case. The user’s ‘proposition’ is not actually stated, and nothing in this opinion concerns standards for modification of a judgment (e.g., family law or support modification) or any typical civil modification context. Therefore, this case does not support a generic proposition offered “in support of the requested modification.”
- Kelly v. Kelly, 412 Mass. 151 (1992).relevant_excerpt: “The defendant asks that we rule that Gomez’s prior recorded testimony not be admitted in the event that she does not testify at a new trial. The Commonwealth is correct in arguing that, generally, a ‘defendant has no standing to contest an alleged infringement of the privilege as it applies to testimony of his spouse.’ … A ‘defendant has no standing to contest an alleged infringement of a privilege he could not have exercised.’”

- Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The “proposition” given is incomplete; it only says the case is cited in support of a requested modification, without identifying any specific legal rule (e.g., standard for modification, best-interests factors, or domestic-violence considerations). Custody of Vaughn deals with how trial courts must make explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on a child in custody determinations, not with modification standards generally. Without a clear articulated proposition, this opinion cannot reliably be said to support it.
- Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child … will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

- Martin v. Martin, 451 Mass. 1 (2008).proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Martin v. Martin, 451 Mass. 1 (2008).support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is incomplete and does not identify any specific legal rule or modification at issue, but the opinion itself concerns application of the Massachusetts anti‑SLAPP statute (G.L. c. 231, § 59H) to claims for malicious prosecution, abuse of process, and c. 93A. It does not address standards for modifying a judgment or order (such as modification of support, custody, or other family-law relief). Because the case is about anti‑SLAPP burden shifting and petitioning activity, it does not support a generic proposition offered merely as “in support of the requested modification.”
- Martin v. Martin, 451 Mass. 1 (2008).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 231, § 59H, ‘protects the “exercise of [the] right of petition under the constitution of the United States or of the [Commonwealth],’ by creating a procedural mechanism, in the form of a special motion to dismiss, for the expedient resolution of suits designed to deter or retaliate against individuals who seek to exercise their right of petition.” … We conclude that the denial of the special motion to dismiss with respect to count three of the complaint was proper, but that the special motion to dismiss should have been allowed as to counts one and two.”

- Johnson v. Johnson, 430 Mass. 825 (199.proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Johnson v. Johnson, 430 Mass. 825 (199.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Johnson v. Johnson is a Massachusetts murder/ineffective assistance of counsel decision and does not discuss domestic relations, modification of judgments, or any civil relief standards. The user’s ‘proposition’ is incomplete and merely says the plaintiff cites this case, without identifying any specific legal principle; nothing in this opinion concerns modification of an order or similar family‑law relief. Accordingly, this case does not support the (implied) proposition about a requested modification in a Massachusetts civil/family context.
- Johnson v. Johnson, 430 Mass. 825 (199.relevant_excerpt: "We examine the defendant’s contentions under the standard provided for by art. 12 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights to protect a defendant’s right to unimpaired assistance of counsel. That standard is more rigorous than its equivalent under the United States Constitution and is, therefore, more favorable to a defendant. The standard was stated in Commonwealth v. Fogarty, 419 Mass. 456, 459 (1995), as follows: ‘If a defendant demonstrates an actual conflict of interest, art. 12 does not require the defendant to show that the conflict resulted in actual prejudice…’"

- Custody of Esther, 467 Mass. 184 (2014.proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Custody of Esther, 467 Mass. 184 (2014.support_reasoning: The proposition is incomplete and only says the case is cited “in support of the requested modification,” without identifying any modification-related legal rule. The provided text from Custody of Esther (actually an armed robbery/fingerprint sufficiency and probation revocation decision) concerns criminal law, evidentiary sufficiency, expert fingerprint testimony, force in armed robbery, closing argument, and probation revocation. It does not address standards for modifying a judgment, modifying custody, or any civil modification standard, so it cannot support a generic ‘requested modification’ proposition.
- Custody of Esther, 467 Mass. 184 (2014.relevant_excerpt: “A probation revocation hearing involves a two-stage process, in which a judge first determines whether a probationer violated a condition of probation and then, if so, decides whether the violation warrants revocation. … Even when the alleged probation violation consists of a new crime, a judge need find only by a preponderance of the evidence that a violation has occurred.”

- Custody of Emma, 441 Mass. 434 (2004).proposition: In support of the requested modification, the Plaintiff cites the following Massachusetts case law:
- Custody of Emma, 441 Mass. 434 (2004).support_reasoning: The quoted material is a dissent by Chief Justice Marshall addressing Article 44 and the Legislature’s power to change income tax rates and effective dates, not any issue about custody or modification of a custody order. It does not concern family law, best interests of the child, or standards for modifying custody, so it cannot support a proposition about a requested custody modification. The citation appears to be either erroneous or wholly inapposite to the stated proposition.
- Custody of Emma, 441 Mass. 434 (2004).relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the Legislature’s retroactive establishment of May 1, 2002, for the termination of one scheme of taxation on capital gains and the imposition of another might well have caused inconvenience, surprise, and expense to those who devised their tax strategies in reliance on the superseded tax scheme. But the plaintiffs have no constitutional entitlement under art. 44 to any particular income tax rate or taxable event.”

Stevens is a concurrence discussing deference to fact-finders and skepticism about resolving credibility from a transcript, referencing Embers of Salisbury. It does not address any substantive standard or rule for modification (e.g., of a judgment, order, or family-law decree), nor does it set out criteria relevant to a requested modification. - Stevens v. Stevens, 425 Mass. 144 (199.relevant_excerpt: "If credibility is to be resolved on the basis of a dry transcript, a doubtful proposition at best, then appellate judges are in as good a position to make that determination as is the tribunal from which the matter is being appealed. Because the court has rejected the views I expressed in Embers of Salisbury, Inc., I see no reason to contest further except to note the remarkable efficiency of the board here..."
